name: Nightmares from the Deep: The Cursed Heart
description: Would you like to enter a thrilling Pirates world where danger lurks in every corner?You are a museum owner pursuing an undead pirate who kidnapped your daughter. You quickly realize that the villain is entangled in a tragic, centuries-old love story, and wants to resurrect his mistress with the girl’s life force.

reviews.review_text: Hidden object and adventure.  Highs: I was impressed by the animation that went into portions of the game. It went beyond the usual throw-in story of most hidden object adventures.  The plot was decent and you were reminded pretty constantly of what was going on by contextual clues.  The location of the next hidden-object puzzle is usually hidden in the most-current location (a picture, etc) otherwise you can just spam the hint button and it will get you to the right area. High resolution puzzles made it easy to pick out the items that were required and lots of hidden object puzzles were present in the game (with only a couple of exceptions)  Lows: The doubling back to the 'guardian' to unlock the chest that takes like 20 doubloons to open was kind of annoying. It isn't required throughout the game, but that's not made apparent while you're playing. A couple of the puzzles had sections that were a bit hazy and fuzzy on large monitors.  All in all, this was a good game. I enjoyed the story. Not so much the fact that you were a talking character (and female at that) which disconnected me from the main character a bit. But, still it's a game and it was a good one even if some of the sequences were pretty obvious.

Largely paralleling Disney's Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest, Nightmares from the Deep: The Cursed Heart is a hidden object game (HOG) that compensates its lack of substance and numerous narrative issues with excellent production values and a continuation of Artifex Mundi's proven casual adventure game formula.  The consistent poor delivery of a story so full of tone and logical issues is by far the worst aspect of the experience. Though I wouldn't say I expect much from games of the genre, The Cursed Heart was an unexpected low for a developer that I know to be better than what they showcased here. It's shallow, abysmally voiced, and weighs down an otherwise mostly enjoyable game. It's hovers right between ignorable and so-bad-it's-good, but winds up more obnoxiously persistent than anything else.  A slightly awkward world to navigate combined with the often unclear objectives were also a bit annoying, in the sense that I had to continually check my map for where to go as opposed to a more natural form of progression. Despite these issues I would still consider The Cursed Heart worth checking out if you've exhausted the rest of the developer's catalog. Its high production values and addicting game design (the reason for which I'm still trying to figure out) are as exceptional as ever, it's mainly the developer's pedigree which brings the experience down, having demonstrated a better knack than most for the genre and in doing so set a higher standard which they as are also going to be judged against.

First game in a present three game series.  Story: Museum Director Sarah Black is putting together an exhibition surrounding pirates and one pirate captain in particular, Captain Henry Remington. Unwittingly Sarah triggers 'ancient' magic and revives the cursed Captain. Captain Remington upon his revival steals Sarah's daughter, Cory. Of course, Sarah follows and stows away on Captain Remington's summoned 'ghost' ship as it sets sail for Captain Remington's island. As Captain Remington's story unfolds the player discovers his personal history, his cursed 'life' and why he stole Sarah's daughter. Sarah with the help of a surprising ally convinces Captain Remington that what he wants to do will only cause more tradegy.  Gameplay is basically set up to occur in three distinct arenas, the museum, Remington's ship, and Remington's island. The tragic tale of Captain Remington is revealed through the various characters (mostly his undead crew, who were cursed when he was, assuming the player talks to them). Rather reminscent of the 'Pirates of Caribbean' first movie and the tale of 'The Flying Dutchman'. Captain Remington's entire tale is told by the Guardian of Remington's chest, which contains the collateral of Remington's Davy Jone's bargain, whenever coins are found and given to the Guardian. Very keeping with the Davy Jones motif and legends.   The puzzles are classic, nothing hard or head scratching. The game even includes a 'treasure hunt'. (When I saw the 'treasure' map, it reminded me of 'Treasure Island'.) There are enough hidden object scenes to keep this a Hidden Object game. The puzzles and hidden objects scenes are intergrated well enough into the storyline that they do not stand out, which in my opinion is a very good thing. However, since the gameplay arenas are limited to three areas there is a lot of back and forth movement within the area until everything is completed. Some may find this annoying but the amount of things needed to be done and accomplished within the area keeps the gameplay moving.   Being the first Artifex Mundi game I have ever played I found I enjoyed the well written storyline as well as the overall gameplay. This game would and did bring me back to buy more, not only of this series, but other games by them, as well.

Got this in a bundle and played it for the cards, but I must say, if you are into hidden item/Myst-style games, this is a very good game to get. For the price, I think you will get a reasonable amount of play time in.  The artwork is appealing and the Pirate Zombie theme is great if you like that. Puzzles are not too challenging, and there is definitely a lot of backtracking throughout the map. The skip functionality doubles as a hint tracker that recharges, ensuring that you wont be stuck for too long.  There is also a find-the-items minigame (among all the other minigames) and you can play mahjong as an alternative and I thought that was really nice.  The story is meh, nothing too special, but for the price I would personally wait for it to go down before purchasing (but I am also very frugal lol)

This game is one of those casual hidden object games, which one can find plenty of around. The game nods continuously towards 'Pirates of the Caribbean' and similar 'Cursed pirate stories', which could be a plus or a minus depending on your personal preferences. It does boast rather nice background art and multiple 'exotic' objects to manipulate from 'all around the world'. There is also a variety of ages where objects come from - modern, XVII-XVIII century and end of XIX century (if you care to go for a 'bonus' adventure available under 'Extras'). Some of the foreground objects look a bit cheap, though, and cutscene video quality is really way too low. While being very accessible overall (as a casual game should be) 'Nightmares' does not explain everything (like 'Skip by playing Mahjong' option or how to start hidden object minigames) very well in the beginning. However, there are no giant mechanical flaws in it, and the ones existing do not detract too much from the experience. Although the voice acting and overall sound assets are so-so, they do help to complete the 'pirate mystery' atmoshpere. The storyline is super-simple and although it tries to add a couple of twists, overall there is nothing grasping about it. There is a little humor to be had and there are even a couple of jokes that might make you smile, but overall the game tends to overplay 'serious mystery' part a little bit too much for my taste. A couple of cheap jumpscares are also available. Having completed all of the available adventures I can say that the game does provide some casual fun for those, who appreciate the appropriate setting and do not mind to solve some simple puzzles (with ample hints available). Overall it is a good title to buy in a bundle and casually enjoy when you don't want to strain yourself or spend much time with a game. Perhaps, it could also be worth a try for HOG fans when on >75% discounts.

Top end in it's genre.  I realy enjoyed this game.  Pro's: - very enjoyable (easy) puzzles. - good hidden objects scenes. - extremely good graphics for it's genre - the option to hover over an object's name to get a shadowy reflection of what the object looks like (realy handy for some of the items if you're not a native english speaker). (Something i realy miss in other hidden object games since i don't know every english word for every item) - option to skip the rest of a hidden objects scene by doing a game of mahjong instead (if you realy can't find an object and don't want to use a hint)  Cons: - voice acting is bad (but that's the case with most of the games in this genre) - just a tiny bit too easy (but that's a quite personal opinion here)
Nice puzzles..... Good storyline :) Recommended for adventure lovers :)

Picked this up in a bundle a little while ago, just got round to having a go....... i couldnt stop myself, had to play through to the end, Great game. great atmosphere and intriguing puzzles. One of the best of its kind.
good game but short =)  4/5

Picked up Nightmares from the Deep: The Cursed Heart during a sale. This was my first Hidden Object Game, didn't even knew this sort of games existed. :) You play a female museum curator whose daughter is kidnapped by an undead pirate. Quickly you find yourself in hot pursuit to set her free. The game is the first part of a trilogy. While I didn't have high hopes for this game, I quickly found myself hooked on progressing through the game. The main game is a point & click adventure, but combined with 3 types of sub-games. First there are puzzles, which are usually not too difficult to solve. Second there are the hidden object games, where you need to find a list of objects in a single scene. And third, mahjong. Mahjong? Rather strange, as Caribbean piracy was already stopped by the time this Chinese tile game was created... I found the game addictive as you quickly pass puzzle by puzzle and the story line opens up. Not a must-play game, but quite entertaining.  Score: 7/10  Pro:  + nice graphics + steady game progress + decent story + additional bonus story  Contra: - maybe a bit too short?

This game is strangely compelling for a casual adventure game that focuses heavily on hidden object puzzles. The difficulty  isn't really there - you'll breeze past this game, even on expert mode (and really, you need to play this on expert mode for this to be even remotely challenging).  That being said, despite most of my time being put into roguelikes or twitchfests these days, I found this to be a great way to spend an afternoon as I downed tremendous amounts of coffee (typically how I like to spend Sundays). Like I said, the difficulty is hardly anything to shake a stick at, but the game is pretty good at providing feedback loop to the player to always make it feel like you're making progress. The story is somewhat of a joke, but I can safely say that the 12-year-old me would have probably loved this game to death. The guy over twice his age... you know what? I liked it for what it was.  One caveat, however, is if you're going to 100% the game (which I did, so that's saying something, right?) you might not enjoy a second trip around as you'll need to play the game twice to get every cheevo. Normally I don't do this, but it was too easy to pass up. So why is playing it twice so bad?  The game offers an alternative most of its hidden object puzzles (there are secondary HOGs to play that make absolutely no effort to hide anything; they are thematic bits to vary up the found-something-in-the-pile method of providing the player items) in the form of 'Mahjong'. First off, I hate that anyone calls the matching game of mahjong tiles 'Mahjong'. It's Shanghai, and Shanghai sucks! If the game had real mahjong, I'd probably enjoy it a lot more (and no way that's going to happen). However, if HOGs aren't your thing, but you would prefer to match tiles to pass puzzles, you're welcome to do that. And you can't possibly fail, either as getting to a stalemate simply reshuffles the stack... which will affect your achievement hunt.  So, in conclusion: - Great time waster with some interesting if not terribly difficult puzzles - 'Mahjong' tile matching will shrivel your sack and must be suffered if you want to 100% the game - Recommended, but you might want to hunt for it in a bundle. It is not worth the price of admission, even with the extra scenario packed in for 'collectors' - Alternatively, get it elsewhere (cheevos are also in-game and just as useful off of Steam as they are on it) for much less.

This game has some of the best art out of all of the hidden objet games I have played, but also some of the worst translations. The game is easy enough, but some of the words for the items are just wrong. Would take only a few minutes to correct, so weird they haven't. Enjoyable game nevertheless. 8/10
Stroyline is okay 8/10 Puzzles 9/10 Overall game 8/10

This game is a typical point and click adventure including mahjong, finding hidden objects and other various puzzles along the way. Although you can find many games like this on the web for free I think it`s worth getting this one on sale or in a bundle. Gameplay lasts for around 4 hours and both the pirate story and puzzles should keep you entertained during a whole playthrough.

A very enjoyable casual game.  The puzzles aren't too difficult, the hidden object areas are enjoyable but am glad they have put in an option to play Mahjong if you aren't into playing the hidden object areas or are having issues finding those last couple of items. The story is also well done and keeps you wanting to play till the end.

Quick, light, entertaining nonsense. I'd check out pretty much all the Artifex Mundi titles on here if you like adventure games, female protagonists, and cheesy horror. They won't rock your world, but they can at least pleasantly vibrate your afternoon.
Great guilty pleasure game. Sure, the voice over's are a bit cheesy but the puzzles and hidden object searches are good fun and never overly frustrating.

One of the best hidden object games I've played so far. It has a solid story, solid game play and the voice acting is actually decent. I guess my only issue is that the extra storyline was short, but it was still nice and answered a question that was lingering after the end of the game.  If you're into this genre of games then you'll probably like this one. It has a fair amount of hidden object scenes mixed with other types of puzzles. There is also a helpful map which clues you in on which area to go to next so you can keep progressing. Though some hidden object scenes get revisted and they're not as challenging the second time around.  Story is rather straight forward and doesn't have that many twists and turns, you can figure it out pretty quickly. But it's still told well and who doesn't like pirates?!  Long story short, buy the game.
This is a great adventure game. Its not those type of adventure games where if you get stuck, you would need to go to a walkthrough. Would recommend.

I had a fun time playing this game. A very fun adventure to be had here ladie. Great cutscenes and the voices were done well. Its interesting almost of the these games feature a leading lady for the hero. Very cool. I never got stuck and really wanted to find out what was going to happen in the end. The bonus adventure is a nice touch as well. A great game. Look for other games this company makes as well I have played them and there all very good.

Very bad game. Unless you are 4 years old, you will not like it. - Extremely bad narration. It makes me cringe all the time.  - Completely random and meaningless puzzles. They never make any sense. - Perfect example of railroading. You never have any choice, and the solution is always obvious. - Absurdly easy. - The characters have no charism at all. They are walking clichés without a personality. Seriously. Don't buy this.

This is one of the best examples of a Hidden Object Game I've played. Quality graphics, decent story, intelligent puzzles, challenging but fair hidden object scenes; even a way to play Mahjongg layouts instead of the Hidden Objects if you so prefer. The only complaint I have is that the map doesn't allow instant travel between locations; beyond that it is an extremely helpful map (actually highlighting what rooms have activities available). Everything played very well, and the bonus adventure was actually pretty good too. I was really impressed with the overall quality; this is a high water mark for a Hidden Object Game.

Did enjoy the game and would recommend but doesn't pose much of a challenge and so doesn't last very long.  A lot of hidden object games, these are pretty funny but no real variation. You can opt for a different type of puzzle instead of HOG, mahjong, but again pretty simple.  The game does look nice and the plot is ok, although nobody is too phased by the whole dead pirate coming back to life! Just another day at the museum....   Personally prefer the point and click style games that are a bit harder to solve

A very plesant game. if you want to fall in a pirate story... hunting shadows and solving misteries - this game is for you. A very nice atmosphere. Every step (or every doublon) make you closer to solving a diabolic mistery. I recommend this game.

A good hidden object game for kids, maybe up to teen years.  Very responsive on a MacBook, very little wait between locations. Character animations left a lot to be desired in many locations. Voice acting was acceptable. Story / plot was there and not bad, but left me wanting for something more… polish, content, decisions and consequences, etc.. The game has good ideas and potential which a small studio probably doesn’t have resources to fulfill, which limits the audience age.

One of the better HOGs I've played on steam, a very enjoyable game. For being all haunted pirate themed, it's not too scary, only a few very mild jumpscares in the game.  You play a museum conservator who is about to display the corpse of the legendary pirate captain Remington in your museum. You manage to wake him up and he kidnaps your daughter in his haunted ship. You'll have none of that and axe your way into his ship to get her back.   There are two areas; the haunted ship and Skull Island. The difficulty of both the hidden object scenes and other minigames is pretty good, neither too hard nor too easy. If you're stuck on a hidden object scene, you can choose to play mahjong instead. in the mahjong there are a few matches of different colour that takes away one HO item each, you can switch back and forth or just play either. There is however an achievement for both playing all mahjong games and finding all HO items without using hint, so an achievement completeist will have to play the game through twice. Luckily for that all conversation and cutscenes are skippable.  All HO scenes are used more than once, and all found items are removed each time, making the 3rd go around pretty easy.   The art is beautiful, the voice acting is good and the music and sound effects set a good haunted-pirate themed mood. The animations in the cutscenes is probably the worst part of the game; they get so bad it feels blurry.   The story is very good, to save your daughter you have to find out what's going on with the pirate captain and you learn his story through collecting and handing in dubloons to the pirate's cute-creepy companion.  There are maps available on both locations but they're useless as it only tells you where you are and cannot be used for teleporting or seeing if an area is cleared.  Highly recommended for any fan of HOGs, pirates or really games in general.

Pros: * Colourful eye candy pictures * Relaxing puzzles, I like the Mahjong game. * Classic Artifex Mundi, you get what you expect in terms of puzzles.  Cons: * This is the first in a trilogy, and sort of introducts the main story. I find this first storyline quite boring and I don't feel driven to finish the game to find out what happens, because the main dilemma, to save my daughter, doesn't feel compelling at all, because the daughter seems to be a whiny brat. * The voice acting is bad, it feels like stock voice acting without any depth or feeling to it. * A bit too much walking back and forth to a certain area to deliver story advancing items. They have solved it better in the 2nd game, which has the same kind of mechanism. * Sometimes when you ask for a hint in certain types of the puzzles, instead of hinting, the game solves the whole puzzle for you. * There is only casual and expert mode, no in between.  Comment: I played it on casual difficulty. Worth it if you can get it on sale and like these types of games, would NOT pay full price. It's worth playing because it lays the background for the next game, which imo is better.  Grade: 5/10

The game is nice to look at (especially the artwork). Voice acting and videos are alright considering the low price of the game (at least on sale). The puzzles are not to challenging and highly repetitive. I bougth it yesterday and finished it within roughly 5 hours ... All in all buy it on sale (I paid 1,24€) or leave it since you are only getting have a day of playtime.

If you like this kind of game and get it cheap, then yes I can recommend it. Otherwise no.  My biggest disappointment are the 480p cutscenes. Would at least think they had bothered rendering some HD cutscenes for a computer game.

A beautiful game with lots and lots of details. A story that can be played through in a few hours, with some quite nice riddles. A pity that the animated sequences aren't as high quality as the rest of the game.
Nice casual game. Not to hard in the hidden object scene when we can switch to mahjong mode.

I got this as part of a bundle and it was great value. There were a few times I had to run around the map a lot in order to find out what to do next, but in a way I appreciated not having my hand held by the game and having to figure some things out.

Done in 3.5h including bonus adventure.  Really liked this one, great graphics and good writing. But no way I'm doing it twice just for achievements (you'd need to do all scenes as hidden object then all scenes as mahjong..)

Wow. Talk about being positively surprised! I went into this expecting nothing more than bare-bones hidden-object fun, and ended up actually getting invested in the story! Granted, the 'frame story' of you being a museum director trying to rescue her daughter (only referred to, again and again, as 'My daughter' - apparently you never named her) is a little wonky, but once you get to Skull Island things change: Slowly you start to learn more about Captain Henry Remington and his fate and his story is... surprisingly well done!  The game has a strange Mahjong alternative to the hidden object-scenes (probably put in there for people who don't like hidden object puzzles but then... why would you have bought this game to begin with?), and those can be fun as well - although you tire of them quickly. Then there's the point-and-click puzzle solving which works like an adventure game 'light' - most of the time you'll have no problem figuring out what to do (although I got stuck once or twice).  In the end, this surprised the hell out of me. I had no idea hidden object games could actually be, you know, good games!
If you like Hidden Object games, this game should be on the top of your wishlist. Few issues, but still supported (recently patched an issue with last achievement)!

This is a very good game, the storyline is interesting, the graphics are nice-looking, and the overall atmosphere of the whole thing is immersive. I recommend it for everyone, because I think everyone who plays it will like it.

Was a fun play through, took me about 4-5 hours. I thought the majority of the puzzles were a bit simple though. Art is very good looking. Cutscenes are very low quality unfortunately. If you like hidden object games its worth a playthrough.

What I was looking for when I started this game last night was something I could be a little bit detached while playing. I stumbled onto a genre that I actually really love with this Artifex Mundi point and click style game. There are different puzzles, hidden object areas, and side games like Mahjong as you find your way through this haunted pirate adventure.    The hidden object parts were my favorite, I wasn't expecting to be so into this style of game either. After expecting to check it out with a passing interest I actually played through it almost 3 times so that I could get the 100% achievement. It isn't a game or series that you will be able to completely emerse yourself into the characters and story. However, if you want a more casual game to change the pace a little bit, this series is definitely worth a look.    The mini games are interesting, and you will definitely have to put on your problem solving hat from time to time. I found most of the game to be very asthetically pleasing, but there are some parts that don't look so great. The cut scenes especially tend to be very blurry and strange compared to the beautiful artwork displayed in the still scenes. I wasnt expecting to be blown away by that aspect of the game so not having my hopes up surely kept it from pulling me out of the experience. The story is about a museum owner who brings in a pirate exhibit and runs into a barrage of problems. She is harassed by the haunted pirate who sold his soul to Davy Jones eventually ending up on Skull island fighting to right the wrongs caused by the ghastly fiend. It has enough there to keep you interested even though the games are definitely the driving force that keep you hooked. Awesome game to pass the time very fun and with a Pirates of the Caribbean story getting the other 2 for sure :D
Great story, Great graphics, Great gameplay.

This is an older HO game, as the low-def animation makes evident, but even showing its age, it's still a solid middle-of-the-road title. There are plenty of HO screens to play (or to avoid by playing a Mahjong minigame, if that's to your tastes) and while they do repeat, no objects respawn. There's lots of running around, and a pirate/ghost/love story that's rather romantic, if you don't think about it too hard.  On the subject of not thinking too hard, this, like most Artifex Mundi HO games, leans to the easy side of the spectrum, so have no fear of the higher difficulty setting. Also, despite the game already being a respectable length to begin with, there's also a modest bonus chapter.

a very short but decent HOG from Artifex Mundi which is a guarantee for high quality HOG.  pros. high resolution. good sound tracks. decent story. great graphics.  cons. none  for hardcore HOG fans is a should buy. but definatly not for the full price. that price for the length of the gameplay time is not fair.   I highly recommend that game on sale or from a bundle.  i give the game 7/10 due to the short time of gameplay +1 for cards =8/10
